# Connecting with Opal data server
## Login to server and assign study data
```{r, echo=FALSE}
#Load R libraries
library(opal)
library(dplyr)
# Create an opal object with the login information
erasmus_opal <- opal.login()
#Login to Opal server and assign the content of the LASA table(s) to your RStudio environment
opal.assign.table.tibble(erasmus_opal, 'LASA1B', 'LASA.LASA1B',variables = list(''))
LASA1B <- opal.execute(erasmus_opal,'LASA1B')
opal.assign.table.tibble(erasmus_opal, 'LASA1C', 'LASA.LASA1C',variables = list(''))
LASA1C <- opal.execute(erasmus_opal,'LASA1C')
opal.assign.table.tibble(erasmus_opal, 'LASA1D', 'LASA.LASA1D',variables = list(''))
LASA1D <- opal.execute(erasmus_opal,'LASA1D')
opal.assign.table.tibble(erasmus_opal, 'LASA1E', 'LASA.LASA1E',variables = list(''))
LASA1E <- opal.execute(erasmus_opal,'LASA1E')

opal.assign.table.tibble(erasmus_opal, 'LASA1F_socioenviro', 'LASA.LASA1F_socioenviro',variables = list("URBANIZATION_GRADE_2006","PROPORTION_MEN_2006","PROPORTION_WOMEN_2006","PROPORTION_65_OLDER_2006","PROPORTION_UNMARIED_2008","PROPORTION_MARIED_2008","PROPORTION_DIVORCED_2008","PROPORTION_WIDOWED_2008","AVERAGE_HOUSEHOLD_SIZE_2006","AVERAGE_VALUE_DWELLINGS_2006","AVERAGE_INCOME_RESIDENTS_2005","PROPORTION_INCOME_RECIPIENTS_2005","PROPORTION_SOCSECBEN_2006","PROPORTION_DISABILITY_BENEFIT_2006","PROPORTION_UNEMPLOYMENT_BENEFIT_2006"))
LASA1Fa <- opal.execute(erasmus_opal,'LASA1F_socioenviro')
opal.assign.table.tibble(erasmus_opal, 'LASA1_Fwave_Area_Identifiers', 'LASA.LASA1_Fwave_Area_Identifiers', variables = list("municipality", "city", "neighbourhood", "PC4", "PC6"))
LASA1Fb <- opal.execute(erasmus_opal, 'LASA1_Fwave_Area_Identifiers')

opal.assign.table.tibble(erasmus_opal, 'LASA1G', 'LASA.LASA1G',variables = list(''))
LASA1G <- opal.execute(erasmus_opal,'LASA1G')

opal.assign.table.tibble(erasmus_opal, 'LASA1H_socioenviro', 'LASA.LASA1H_socioenviro',variables = list("URBANIZATION_GRADE_2011","PROPORTION_MEN_2011","PROPORTION_WOMEN_2011","PROPORTION_65_OLDER_2011","PROPORTION_UNMARIED_2011","PROPORTION_MARIED_2011","PROPORTION_DIVORCED_2011","PROPORTION_WIDOWED_2011","AVERAGE_HOUSEHOLD_SIZE_2011","AVERAGE_VALUE_DWELLINGS_2011","PROPORTION_UNOCCUPIED_DWELLINGS_2012","AVERAGE_INCOME_RESIDENTS_2011","PROPORTION_INCOME_RECIPIENTS_2011","PROPORTION_SOCSECBEN_2010","PROPORTION_DISABILITY_BENEFIT_2010","PROPORTION_UNEMPLOYMENT_BENEFIT_2010","PROPORTION_LOW_EDUCATION_2014","PROPORTION_INTERMEDIATE_EDUCATION_2014","PROPORTION_HIGH_EDUCATION_2014","NUMBER_CRIMINAL_OFFENSES_PER_1000_RESIDENTS_2011","NUMBER_VANDALISM_PUBLIC_ORDER_PER_1000_RESIDENTS_2011",
"NUMBER_VIOLENT_CRIMES_SEXUAL_OFFENSES_PER_1000_RESIDENTS_2011"))
LASA1Ha <- opal.execute(erasmus_opal,'LASA1H_socioenviro')
opal.assign.table.tibble(erasmus_opal, 'LASA1_Hwave_Area_Identifiers', 'LASA.LASA1_Hwave_Area_Identifiers', variables = list("municipality", "city", "neighbourhood", "PC4", "PC6"))
LASA1Hb <- opal.execute(erasmus_opal, 'LASA1_Hwave_Area_Identifiers')



```
## Assign participant id as first column of your harmonized dataframes
```{r, echo=FALSE}
LASA1F<-merge(LASA1Fa, LASA1Fb, by="id", all=TRUE)
LASA1H<-merge(LASA1Ha, LASA1Hb, by="id", all=TRUE)

socenv_LASA1_0<- data.frame(id= LASA1B$id)
socenv_LASA1_1<- data.frame(id= LASA1C$id)
socenv_LASA1_2<- data.frame(id= LASA1D$id)
socenv_LASA1_3<- data.frame(id= LASA1E$id)
socenv_LASA1_4<- data.frame(id= LASA1F$id)
socenv_LASA1_5<- data.frame(id= LASA1G$id)
socenv_LASA1_6<- data.frame(id= LASA1H$id)
```
## When you are done with your work, logout of Opal server
```{r, echo=FALSE}
opal.logout(erasmus_opal) 
```

# Urbanization grade

### **Variable label**: Urbanization grade in 2006  
**Variable name**: socenv_urbanization_grade_4    
**Variable description**: Population density of the residential area (number of residents per km2) in 2006.  
**Variable type**: integer
**Variable unit**:   
**Category coding**:   

**Harmonization status**:  complete
**Harmonization comment**:  
For LASA, these data are available for neighbourhoods in 2006 and 2011. This variable was already available in the original data source. This variable has been linked to cohort respondents using their 6-digit postal code. References of all data sources are listed in the WP7 deliverable report.
**R script**:  
```{r, echo=TRUE}  
socenv_LASA1_4$socenv_urbanization_grade_4<-as.integer(LASA1F$URBANIZATION_GRADE_2006)
```

### **Variable label**: Average income in 1000 euros in 2005 (dichotomized)  
**Variable name**: socenv_av_inc1000dich_4  
**Variable description**: Average income in 1000 euros of residents in residential area in 2005 (dichotomized: below/above country-specific net mean household income (OECD)).      
**Variable type**: integer     
**Variable unit**:   
**Category coding**:   

**Code** | **Category Label**  
------------- | -------------  
0 | Less than or equal to country-specific net mean household income
1 | Greater than country-specific net mean household income   


**Harmonization status**: complete  
**Harmonization comment**:
We dichotomized average net year income in 1000 euros of residents in the neighbourhood by comparing it with the country-specific net mean household income (OECD-data) in 2005 (€23.895). OECD uses a square root scale which is a scale that divides household income by the square root of household size. We take this correction into account and assume that when the average household size is 2 or above, there are 2 income earners in the household.
The income variable has been calculated as follows: 
if hh_size<2, income_correction= income*hh_size/sqrt(hh_size)
if hh_size>=2, income_correction= income*2/sqrt(hh_size)
Subsequently, the corrected income variable has been compared with the OECD value.
**R script**:  
```{r, echo=TRUE} 
socenv_LASA1_4$socenv_av_inc1000dich_4 <-
ifelse((as.numeric(LASA1F$AVERAGE_HOUSEHOLD_SIZE_2006))<2, as.numeric(LASA1F$AVERAGE_INCOME_RESIDENTS_2005)*as.numeric(LASA1F$AVERAGE_HOUSEHOLD_SIZE_2006)/sqrt(as.numeric(LASA1F$AVERAGE_HOUSEHOLD_SIZE_2006)), as.numeric(LASA1F$AVERAGE_INCOME_RESIDENTS_2005)*2/sqrt(as.numeric(LASA1F$AVERAGE_HOUSEHOLD_SIZE_2006))) 
 
socenv_LASA1_4$socenv_av_inc1000dich_4 <-
ifelse(as.numeric(socenv_LASA1_4$socenv_av_inc1000dich_4) > 23.896, 1, 0)

tab1(socenv_LASA1_4$socenv_av_inc1000dich_4)


```

### **Variable label**: Average income in 1000 euros in 2005 (Z standardised)  
**Variable name**: socenv_av_inc1000Z_4  
**Variable description**: Average income in 1000 euros of residents in residential area in 2005 (standardized: mean=0 and sd=1).
**Variable type**: integer    
**Variable unit**:   
**Category coding**:   

**Harmonization status**: complete  
**Harmonization comment**: 
We standardized average gross year income in 1000 euros of residents in the neighbourhood by using the formula: Z=(x-y)/o (Z=standardized income variable with mean=0, sd=1; x=area-level average income from respondent; y=area-level average income in entire country; o=standard deviation of area-level income in entire country). Based on neighbourhood-level data from Statistics Netherlands, we calculated y and o in 2005 in the Netherlands: y=12.3206 and o=2.42953. Here, this variable is linked to LASA participants at wave 2006.
**R script**:  
```{r, echo=TRUE} 

socenv_LASA1_4$socenv_av_inc1000Z_4 <- (as.numeric(LASA1F$AVERAGE_INCOME_RESIDENTS_2005)-12.3206)/2.42953

```
